Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigation of Sources of Intraplate Volcanism Using PASSCAL Broadband Instruments in Madagascar, The Comores, and Mozambique (MACOMO)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will involve the acquisition and analysis of seismic data from a network of broadband seismometers installed in Madagascar, the Comores Islands, and Mozambique in order to determine the origin of intraplate volcanism in the region. No modern seismic investigation of Madagascar, the world?s 4th largest island, has ever been made, and the source of the volcanism, not near any plate boundary, is unknown. This study seeks to determine if the volcanism is connected with either the giant lower mantle large low-shear velocity province (LLSVP) or with any of the upper mantle hot spots such as those beneath Afar or Reunion. The seismometers, borrowed from the IRIS PASSCAL pool of instruments, will be deployed in two installations: 18 in the summer of 2011 (in Madagascar, the Comores, and Mozambique), and 15 in the summer of 2012 (all in Madagascar). All seismometers will be retrieved in the summer of 2013. The broadband seismic data will be analyzed using several techniques in order to determine the sub-surface structure of the region. Both surface and body wave data will be use to generate 3D tomographic images of the crust and mantle; shear-wave splitting will be used to examine anisotropic fabric; P-to-S-wave conversions will be used to generate receiver functions for determining topography on the Moho and other sub-surface discontinuities.

The African LLSVP is the largest seismic anomaly within the earth; as an enormous thermochemical boundary layer between the mantle and core, it plays a vitally important role in controlling the nature of vertical mass flux within the mantle, and therefore of both mantle convection and its manifestation at the surface as plate tectonics. The African LLSVP is thought to play an important role in the abundant occurrence of hot spot volcanism on the African plate, but the mechanism by which this occurs is not known due to the extremely limited data sampling available at this location in the Southern Hemisphere. Further study of the sub-African LLSVP will be of interest to earth scientists in many disciplines, as will providing the first study of the sub-surface geology of Madagascar. This project will help in the training of U.S. graduate students as well as scientists in Madagascar and Mozambique, and will help strengthen the scientific ties between these three countries. This project will also be a scientific partner with AfricaArray, which has been a unifying positive force of science and good will in Africa.

This award is co-funded by NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data from the MACOMO (MAdagascar COmoros MOzambique) seismic experiment are being used to examine the structure of the crust, lithosphere, asthenosphere, and deep mantle beneath Madagascar. A historic lack of seismic data from Madagascar has prevented geoscientists from understanding many aspects of Madagascar’s tectonic history and its distribution of rocks and resources. A series of publications are in preparation that describe many geologic aspects of Madagascar, including its seismicity, active tectonics, crustal thickness, plate structure, mantle dynamics, and the reasons for recent intraplate volcanism in three separate regions of the world’s 4th largest island. The MACOMO experiment deployed 31 IRIS broadband seismometers across Madagascar (25 stations) and Mozambique (6 stations) for up to two years during 2011-2013. Data analyses are being carried out using data from concurrent French and German experiments.

1) Though Madagascar is an intraplate region with no obvious active plate boundaries (Figure 1), it is unusually seismically active and we located 929 intraplate earthquakes (Figure 2). Most Madagascar intraplate earthquakes are less than 15km in depth, though some are as deep as 30km. The seismicity is largely concentrated in the central and east-central portions of the island, and agrees well with a model that suggests extensional normal-faulting on either side of the north-south-trending mountainous Central Highlands block. Seismicity to the north has predominantly strike-slip focal mechanisms and might be indicative of reactivation of an oceanic fracture zone.

2) Combined receiver functions and Rayleigh wave dispersion curves have provided the first island-wide map of Madagascar’s crustal thickness (Figure 3), which varies from 45-km-thick beneath the spine of the north-south trending central mountain range to less than 20km beneath the western basins. The crystalline continental crust is stretched as thin as 10km in several locations along the western coast of Madagascar, a result of the rifting from mainland Africa that began about 160 million years ago.  As the rifting occurred and crust thinned, the submerged western coast was covered by marine sediments that now form sedimentary rock sequences up to 10km thick. These ancient sedimentary basins may hold significant petroleum resources. The deepest crust, up to 45km thick, runs along the spine of the north-south-trending central mountains, but crustal thicknesses thin significantly toward the north, where topographies are still anomalously high (>1km above sea level) and Bouger anomalies mirror the topography, suggesting some form of non-isostatic uplift of the northern half of the island, perhaps related to the sources of the recent volcanism in the central and northern portions of Madagascar. Along the east coast there are two regions (Angongil and Masaora) of unusually thick crust (~40km) that are slivers of 3.3 billion-year-old ancient craton that got ripped off of India when India broke away from Madagascar and moved north into Asia.
